She even asked us, "WHAT?" as if we were bugging her.  That was the first time we came here.  When we left, the line to get in was very long and almost went out towards the entrance.

The other times we were here was for breakfast.   The omelette station was good as there was a chef there to cook it fresh just the way I wanted.  Our waitress was somebody different than the first time and so much better than the waitress we had the first time we were here.

I thought this place was A-OK.

Tuesday Seafood Night for $17.99 is a steal in Las Vegas.  My family piled our plates high with Snow crab legs, shrimp, and oysters. mMmMmmm... But not every night is Seafood night so here's the schedule! 

Paradise Buffet Dinner Schedule
Prime Rib Night $13.99*
Sunday, Monday and Thursday: 4:00pm - 10:00pm      
Seafood Fantasy $17.99*
Tuesday: 4:00pm - 10:00pm and Friday 4:00pm - 11:00pm      
Steak Night $13.99* 
 Wednesday: 4:00pm - 10:00pm and Saturday, 4:00pm - 11:00pm     


Though it is buffet, the service is excellent, so tip well! :)
Many choices!  Loved it!  And the price is very reasonable.  Great customer service as well.   Beats all the other Buffets I have gone to in the past.

The food is SO not good. Absolutely every single item is heat and serve or defrost and serve. The food is really, really bad, I am NOT exaggerating, BUT it is FREE when you are staying here and/or gambling, therefore it will fill you up. That's all it is, filling and NOTHING else.
Closed on 12/20/14 when Ii visit. So really no stars.  I will just give a in the middle vote

we went here last year on our trip to vegas. we were staying at treasure island and we decided to check out the older vegas and for the price under 10 bucks you cant beat it with a stick. its simple buffet nothing fancy like ti's but it reminds you of what vegas was like in the movies! were going back rhis may and cant wait to come here to eat and shop on fremont street

This buffet is ok. There are many choices to choose from but not as many as Garden Court buffet in Main Street Station. The setting has a "tropical island" theme. The only time thats worth coming here is their seafood night but then again what buffet doesn't have that. Its pretty straight forward food with asian, italian, and  the usual carving station. If you want a taste of old vegas, paradise buffet is for you.

Don't expect a strip type of buffet and you won't be disappointed. Salt is a-plenty and you'll be gulping down waters or sodas to offset the high sodium. The selection is okay for this tired buffet in the heart of the Fremont hotel.

It's like a cliche late night diner but buffet style. You see all types of people walking through and around this place...just like the ones you see getting to it. 

Just like the whole Fremont experience, it's a wonderful bit of entertainment on par with the ambiance DTLV. The price is fair for what you get. But just remember to leave your expectations on the gaming floor.
Pretty standard buffet options but for the price it's a great place to eat downtown Vegas.
Very good breakfast buffet. Got to get a made-to-order omlette!

We ate at this buffet on two occasions during an extended Vegas weekend, where most of our activities were downtown and off-strip.  

I give this buffet a good to very good in my book.   The buffet looks older; however, still elegant and classy at the same time.  

The service was very friendly.  Both times we had excellent attendants and they were prompt at checking on us as well as bringing us drinks and clearing our plates.

We found most of the food to be good to very good; however, there were some things we really didn't care for.  Now, is this a bad thing? Not really....at a buffet we expect there to be some things we don't like and some things we do.  I would say this buffet ranked in the middle for us taste wise; however, the price was right -- so we likely would return again based on the value.

Seriously there's lots of food selection for such a great price. The place is really dark and yes they could use more lights but hey maybe it adds to the ambiance of an old town feel. There are so many food options that even my daughter is able to go back and forth. And that's pretty good cause she's a picky eater. This place is one of mine and hub's favorite spot for an AYCE.

This is one of those buffets akin to Ryan's or Golden Corral where everyone at the table kinda stares at their "food" and then one another like "This is probably a baaad idea...". One of those where you're genuinely concerned about what the aftermath will be. The only saving grace is that I didn't turn up with food poisoning.

I don't get how this place got so many good reviews. I would definitely not recommend going on seafood night - it's more expensive and the selection is a joke. I could probably list on 2 hands the variety of items offered.

The sushi was not sushi. It was a shitload of rice surrounding unidentifiable gray stuff. That's not an exagerration for comedic purposes.

The peel & eat shrimp were small and flavorless. The shrimp with shells on were seasoned and actually really tasty but messy. The crab legs were typical buffet crab legs.

Aside from the seafood, they had mushy spaghetti, cold bread, old veggies and some very unattractive looking meat specimens.

The desserts were a joke.

Pay the extra money and head to the Bellagio buffet. This place was sickening.

You can get a 2 for 1 coupon online which would make it well worth the trip. However I paid full price ($15) and was rather disappointed with what was available. At that price point I get alot more seafood selection and better quality sushi at a place back home.

I stopped by since they advertised fresh sushi for the dinner and the sushi was not very fresh at all. The rice was slimy and they packed a ton of rice with a small amount of fish. The selection of rolls was pretty pitiful - they had tuna rolls, shrimp nigiri and a roll with seawood inside.

I went on a Sunday night which was "prime rib" night. The prime rib was tender and they had all the condiments you would want with it (parmasean, horseradish, etc) which was good.

I loved their Mexican section. They had some mildly spiced carne asada with fresh cilantro as well as guacamole, pico de gallo, sour cream, lettuce and more. I was able to make an awesome taco salad.
I've had buffets at other casinos but I got to say this one was really good. The food wasn't dry and it was so tasty. We loved it!!

Instead of LUNCH, I hit this buffet up for dinner mainly because they offered sushi.

The decor is dark wt mirrored walls but nice enough with big plush comfortable booths wt strong direct lighting on the table good for reading a paper.

I hit up the sushi bar first and the rolls are large cuts and limited to cali, tuna & some mystery roll (?) the wasabi was dry and had very little kick at all. I accompanied the rolls wt peel & eat garlic shrimp that had been cooked then iced down and it had a mushy texture wasnt very nice at all. The crab salad was tasty enough and helped make the roll a little better. Overall a big disappointment.

Next up was the Mexican station and I made a plate of "Super Nachos" wt a bed of crispy chips wt a hearty spoonful of pulled pork, ground beef and pulled chicken in a tomato sauce & added guacamole, some refried beans, mexican rice and sour cream. I ended up  adding some much needed salt & mixing it all up and it was better tasting than when I was picking at the individual sections. This was better than the limited & lame sushi station. I had also got a pc of fried chicken and it turned out to be on the cold side and I stopped eating it.

Next up was the chinese station  offering 3 or so dishes of Beef Brocoli, chicken in some sauce wt thick cut onions & peppers. I tried both combining them and it was OK. There was some Lo mein and Chines noodles I passed on and NO spring rolls.

Last up was desert and the selections seemed many and looked quite good. I tried the Coconut cream pia wt some soft serve ice cream and it was good enough to have 2 pcs. There was more cream than coconut filling but at least the crust was good.

This was kind of pricey coming in at around $17 and not really worth it at considered the lacking quality and offerings. I might add that this night I went was "Prime Rib" night and while I didnt try any, it looked OK.

I doubt I will be going back if I'm in the area and will stick wt the Golden Nugget over The Freemont as the quality was in line wt the price.

My aunt and uncle came into town the other day, so I decided to take them sightseeing downtown! My uncle had to use the restroom, so we walked into the closest casino, which happened to be Fremont! When everyone was done using the restroom, my aunt saw the huge "Seafood Buffet" sign right outside of the restrooms, and that is how it began...

It was a Friday night, which meant Seafood. The seafood buffet was $20.99 per person. We were all hungry, so we made the best of it! My friend and I had a strategy... and that strategy was to ONLY EAT SEAFOOD!

The 2 stars for this review definitely goes to the Giant Crawfish! I HEART CRAWFISH! So... GUILTY, I had about 2-3 plates full of crawfish =X. There was also crab legs, which were alright, extremely small. I did enjoy the smoked salmon and fried oysters. The peeled shrimp on the other hand? They were BAD... They looked very dark, I did not even want to try them! The sushi was not good. The rice had seemed to harden from sitting in the open all day. Aside from the seafood, the rest of the food selection was very minimal.

It was then time for dessert. Luckily they had banana cream pie! It wasn't the best, but it was okay.

Overall, nothing too spectacular about this buffet. I don't think I'll be paying another $21 to eat here...

The thing I love about Vegas is for the price of a appetizer you can eat at a buffet.  Paradise Buffet, located in the Freemont Casino, is your stereotypical cheap Vegas buffet with tons of food items but lacking in quality

Parking:
Parking available in the Freemont Casino.  

Atmosphere:
Kinda tacky. Think of dark rain forest, mirrors and green vinyl booths. All that and a big buffet.   I'm pretty sure this restaurant was featured in "Swingers" as the place the guys got dinner after they lost the money at the tables.

Service:
This restaurant is both a Buffet and standard restaurant service.  For the handful of times I've been service has been fine without complaints. For both the Buffet and standard service waiters have been attentive and fast. If you have any problems its just getting into the place where if you go buffet you pre pay.

Cost:
So for the Buffet it ranges from $7-8(breakfast & lunch) to $20(Tues night Seafood).  For the most part the standard buffet you're going to get your money worth for $14 although for Seafood night you could do better.  For standard restaurant service  most food ranges from $6-11 so depending on what time you go and what you want to eat it might be a better deal just to get the buffet.

Food:
Like many Las Vegas buffets the food is just alright.  Well at least nobody ever got sick when they were with me.   I think the weekend breakfast brunch was my most favorite just do selection.  The times I've been the dessert selection was rather good.

Conclusion:
Paradise Buffet is just your typical Vegas cheap buffet. Nothing amazing but your also not breaking the bank to get some food.  It's a bit tacky but if you get by that then its definitely worth it for breakfast or lunch(weekdays)
Not a very large selection, over priced, and not very attentive wait staff. Save yourself the trip and go to the buffet at main street station, much bigger and better selection!

This buffet should coat $10 it's not enough variety of different types of food for $13. I didn't like the food at all was very disappointed, "Texas Station" was ten times better and half the price. I will not be back.

We've ate here before. You'd thought we'd learned the first time. Our food was all barely even warm. The crab legs are boiled, not steamed so they're very soggy and difficult to crack. Theydo have oystes, mussels and clams if you're into that. The service was just mediocre, taking along time to clear tables and bring refills. On a positive the place clean just a lil outdated and the ice cream is good.

I give it 2 stars because I mostly feel everything was underwhelming.  Nothing really stood out to me, I even witnessed a couple that wanted a refund after they saw the lack of options. I've never eaten here before and probably won't be back. I tried it and now my life can go on. 

Some of the meats under the warmer didn't taste fresh. The taste of it reminded me of great grandmothers and my feelings don't have anything to do with all the great grandmother's surrounding me.

Well-priced buffet ($13.50) for brunch with players card. While it was smaller than strip buffet, I found the choices to be a great variety, because there were options from breakfast, lunch, and dinner. There was an omelette station and carving station, which were unexpected, but welcomed for the price. Additionally, there were some creative additions that I had never eaten before - such Mexican pot pie and crawfish salad (very good if you like something with an after kick). The staff was very friendly and attentive. All in all, a great value for the budget-conscious tourist who appreciates the vintage aesthetic of Old Vegas.

My review only concerns the Saturday Champagne Brunch we went to today Saturday 9/29. The wait time in line to the cashier is good! Unlike Palms or M they move their line & seat guests promptly. The one who seated us was a little gruff, we requested a booth & she said we are busy take what we have, but she quickly led us to a booth of which they have plenty. The champagne was free flowing, the server was attentive. They have stone crab claws & peel & eat shrimp & the prime rib was delicious. Good salad & dessert selections too. For the $11.99 price each with B card can't be beat. Highly recommend

Terrible. Very bad. Not good. 

Food was low quality, served in a very unappealing manner.  Prime Rib cooked Medium to well. Very strange texture for a roast of any type.

I see a lot of bad reviews here, but what did ya'll honestly expect for the cheap price??? My boyfriend and I both ate for 32$ total and it wasn't too bad. The roast beef was perfect! And for a Buffett, the service wasn't that bad. You're in old town Vegas. If you want high class, go to the strip. Otherwise, quit bitchin because you got what you paid for.

Not a bad buffet to try in D Town LV. 

There`s typically a line to get in but the line moves relatively fast.  

All you can eat seafood (I.e. Various types of fish cooked diff styles, crab legs, smoked salmon, shrimp,fresh and fried oysters, calamari,  steamed blue crabs, steak, turkey, seafood pastas  and soups etc)

friendly servers too

Our favorite downtown buffet, by far!  Champagne brunch with stone crab legs... yum!  Our server was awesome.. and kept our drinks full.. I think i tried a tiny bit of everything, and it was all delicious.  I think I filled up on champagne though... When i stood up to leave, i felt it!  

Bonus - We had a 2 for 1 coupon, so champagne brunch for two was $9.99!!   

During our most recent trip to Vegas, in Dec ... paradise buffet was closed :*( I think they opened back up the day we were leaving...  hubby was sad :( lol..
The food not bad for the price. Service is good. The decor reminds me of Rainforest cafe. Overall nice experience.

So my grandparents paid for the whole weekend trip thankfully. But honestly i would have rather eaten fast food the entire trip then come to this buffet 3 different times. Every time i filled a plate i couldn't finish it because the food was so gross. The meat was so tough i couldn't swallow. The desserts were very cheap and obviously not made in house. The rest of the dinner items were just gross. The only good thing i liked about this place was the bottomless mimosa breakfast.

Recently went here for lunch and was not to impressed was about average. I have gone here for dinner buffet before and it is a bit better especially if you like crab legs and go  on a seafood night. My girlfriend loves their seafood buffet but thought lunch was one star horrible. It is hard to screw up tacos but I liked them very much during lunch but thought was unsanitary they had soft shells just sitting in a plastic warmer with no utensils to put them on your plate .

I will give an honest and fair review of this buffet 
considering, price, quality and taste.

I have been to this buffet several times for breakfast
only and can truly say it is very good for the price 
and I look forward to eating here every visit.

 The price is one of the lowest in all of Vegas and 
weighing all out this buffet has good breakfast and 
considering Mc D's and Burger King is about $5 for A 
breakfast that is small and cheap, you get reasonable 
bacon, eggs, freshmade to order tasty omelette's with 
fresh eggs cracked right in front of you, fruit, veggies, 
desserts, shrimps, salads, and much more for A very
 low price.


 This is a buffet that has reasonably good food that is 
very good for the price, and I recommend their made to
 order omelettes so you can pick what you like and 
have it made in front of you.


In conclusion, where on earth can you get quality fresh 
made unlimited omelettes, bacon, eggs, fruit, bacon, 
sausages, desserts, and so many other options that 
are reasonably good in the year  2015 and after for less 
than $8 bucks with a server bringing you unlimited bever-
ages and on top of that all items are reasonably good
and tasty.  All in a nice nostalgic dining area with nice
plants to accent the paradise theme?  To expect expen-
sive gourmet food for a low price would be unreasonable
in my opinion. 

Try other buffets and you will pay double for similar food.

This is a tough review for me to write.  The food was mediocre, which come on, is what you expect on a buffet, and if that were the sum of my experience at the buffet, I would have given the Paradise Buffet more stars.  

However, I am 99% sure I had some bad oysters on the buffet.  Which, shame on me, I live in Louisiana so have no business eating oysters in the middle of the desert 1500 miles from The Gulf. 

So, that was a downer.

But, I'm a lover of kitsch. And the Paradise Buffet has this in spades, in an un-ironic, before the hipsters took over sort of way.  The dining room looks like it is a leftover set from The Golden Girls, but with more tropical floral patterns and crystal chandeliers. 

Now the food itself.  I went to the Seafood Spectacular, or whatever it's called, and  had a coupon.  There were piles of seafood in every direction.  And they split the crab legs for you because as Americans, that's something we can't even do anymore.  And like I said, aside from the suspected bad oysters, it was all mediocre, so just kind of meh.

If you're set on having seafood, you could do worse.  But, if you're just looking for cheap eats, head across the street to The Four Queens and chow down on the $8.95 Prime Rib Dinner, which was actually very good.

Viva Las Vegas!
the paradise buffet is one of the best on a Sunday morning the food is very good and the staff takes excellent care of their customers it's the best one downtown on Fremont street/ Bodacious

Service + Restaurant Interior: 3/5
Price vs. Quantity: 4/5
Food Taste: 3/5

I've eaten at Paradise Buffet twice now. Both times I've had the same experience which was just O.K. So they get props for consistency. The biggest draw point for this buffet is the price. It's one of the cheapest buffets I've been to. The food quality, however, is lacking.

The restaurant interior is a little too dim for my taste with a cheap tropical feel. The place is clean though which gets points since it's a buffet and those tend to get dirty. The wait staff shows up sporadically, not the most attentive.

The best thing they have is hands down the fried shrimp. It tastes delicious, especially with some lemon and cocktail sauce. They are pretty large in size and fried to a point where each bite provides a crunch. The taco bar was pretty impressive too. They have numerous taco toppings including some refried beans. They weren't the best taco you'll ever eat but it was unlimited so I was satisfied.

All the Chinese food is mediocre. Most of it is dried out or lacking flavor so I would personally steer clear of that. The sushi is extremely limited in variety. They have a neat little salad/side bar that has various things like pesto pasta salad, ambrosia salad, seafood salad and more. I was actually pleased with that because it gave me a lot of things to try, all of which were so-so (except the ambrosia salad which was great).

They had a stewed meat which was definitely noteworthy as I don't tend to see stew at buffets and it was pretty tasty, but not very tender. The desserts were a nice surprise for the sheer variety that they have. It's more typical stuff like pies and cakes, so don't expect anything unique. The flavor of all the desserts is about what you'd expect, almost like a store bought flavor.

If you're on a budget and not picky then give this place a shot. You probably won't walk away thinking you just had the best meal ever, but it beats paying $30-60 a person at a buffet in the strip.

That was probably the worst buffet I have ever eaten at. There was no variety. No flavor in any of the food. $50 for seafood??? Crab legs, talapia, crawfish & calamari do not constitute $50. OMG, and the so called prime rib, all well done and tough. I am not a fast food eater but would rather eat a McDonalds McRib before going back. Let's just say, was lucky to make it back to our room.

One of the very few one star reviews I have ever written...this place is just a mess, I saw the reviews but I thought I should judge it for myself and boy do I regret that!
The price for the lunch buffet isn't what the advertising said, the staff is very inattentive and sounded bored the entire time, the place is unclean seeing as they prioritize getting people to seats before cleaning them, and most importantly the food is just plain bad.
I had never encountered a place that made me not try to eat everything on my plate especially shrimp bit this place succeeded.

We have eaten at Paradise Buffet it was really good great selection and if you catch the all you can eat steak not bad for the price

I really don't care for buffets, nonetheless one out here.  However, my parents been DTLV for years (my first) and I believe this is their first at Freemont.  
We only been here once for lunch and breakfast on our last day, I've enjoyed their omelette station twice^_^ the man behind the stove did a mini show of tossin and flippin, did an xtra w/them pancakes too.
Mum&Dad didn't care much for the lunch buffet, but fills they tummy with it's worth anyway as they come with the Vacations Hawaii Package. 
Speakin of which, my mum threw down the meal coupons as it was our last day, of them we only used 2-3.  Our server Rose, tells us we could use them at the snack bar for purchase or trade at any of the DT participating hotels.  To my surprise, after 15+ years my parents didn't know of this until now!  My poor dad was snackin on some them Trader Joe's omiyage the other Nite cuz he was hungry when he could've jus used them coupons for sushi or real food!
Mum says no one has ever told them this. If my star rating could go to this server then it's all hers.  I mean, not only she had us learn bout them coupon books...she checked on us more than enough and refilled our coffee even when not asked. She talked to us a bit and she wasn't even filipino!! hahahha 

Rose made a lovely experience after waking up a grouch at 730 in the ayyy emm. Except for that man up front, he must've woke on the wrong side of the bed too, grumpy rude man!

Oh wow, guess Thursday is a bad day. I paid for 5 over $82, I would not bring myself to eat. After looking at the poor quality of offerings and under ripe fruit I could not bring myself the stomach the from a can food. The prime rib is a joke, over cooked and thin sliced.  I know this place has some good reviews but I do not see it and for sure I will not taste it either.  I would suggest trying something else. I will say the glass of ice tea was good and cold.

Second day at am brunch during our Vegas stay.  Had such a great experience yesterday we had to come back...well until greeted by hostess Tiffany who just ruined the experience.  Very rude when asked for a closer table.  My 80 year old mom with a cane had to struggle from the back of the restaurant.  Thank goodness for our waitress's Hagen (sp) who was very friendly and attentive.

During my Vegas trip stay at the Fremont Hotel and Casino I came to the Paradise Buffet to have my breakfast, lunch, or dinner.  Vacation Hawaii provides food vouchers to use at this buffet. Also B Connected Players Club may offer promotion for free breakfast or lunch buffet (check the kiosk daily to see if you have promotion offers).

Breakfast
Fruit bar offered bananas, cantaloupe, honeydew melon, peaches, pears, fruit cocktail, and jello.  Restaurant customers may also choose ham, bacon, sausage patties, little sausages, scrambled eggs, potatoes, rice, biscuits, toasts, miso soup, cold cereal, and other items I can't remember.  LOL. There is the omelette station where you can order your omelette any way you want or order easy over eggs.  The chef, Juan Rios who was April 2014 Employee of the month,  managed to cook the omelettes for the customers as well as replenishing the hot pancakes. 

Lunch/Dinner
Spaghetti, dirty rice, mashed potatoes, roast chicken, fried chicken, ribs, fish, and some other items were offered as well. Carving station had the prime rib and the chicken. Many choices of pies for dessert or settle for soft serve ice cream.

Wait help
I had three different people as my wait help when I had my meals. One waitress (Monday/Tuesday breakfast as well as Monday dinner)  and was really friendly and always checked up on me. She made sure that my coffee never ran out. The waiter during my Wednesday visit for lunch was also was friendly and he too checked up on me. The second waitress during my Thursday breakfast did not even checked up on me nor did I get a coffee refill. 

Overall my experience eating at Paradise Buffet was average. I enjoyed eating the hot pancakes and omelette for breakfast. The miso soup was a bit too salty. The fried chicken was a bit too dry. The mashed potatoes was delicious with the southern beef stew over it. 

Next time I should try the cafe side of Paradise Buffet and Cafe.

You definitely get what you pay for. Even tho we paid the same price here as we did at the Paris buffet last night, the food was dismal. The fresh omelette station was a good addition, but nothing else was worth it. Prime rib was disappointing, if I have to be nice. I mean, all the other prepared foods I can understand...but HOW DO YOU MESS UP SOFT SERVE???!!! Even that sucked...

Located in the Fremont Hotel Casino downtown, while it's not on The Strip, it is a good alternative to the more expensive buffets in some of the other hotel casinos.  The night we were there, there were plenty of options to choose including crab legs and sushi, which was a slight increase in price and alcohol is not included with the buffet.
The olives tasted like they were expired and it smells like cigarette smoke. Any home town buffet is 1000 times better than this place.

Probably closer to 3.5 stars than 4, but the price was right and a 2-for-1 coupon sweetened the deal.

Our champagne brunch was quite nice. We each asked for orange juice with an extra glass so we could mix our own mimosas, and the drink waitress looked surprised but complied. The orange juice was great and fresh tasting, so the mimosas were a highlight.

The prime rib was good. The delicious Korean chicken was the best thing I tried. The lamb was only okay. I didn't much care for the stone crab claws (my least favorite kind of crab). The peel-and-eat shrimp was very pleasantly spiced, another winner. The seafood bisque was okay; the soup itself was good but the plentiful seafood was not very appealing and brought it down a notch. (Fake crab, a few tasteless scallops, and tiny shrimp that didn't seem to make any difference other than to give you something to chew.)

The hash -- apparently a big favorite of Hawaiians -- was only adequate, straight from the can and heated the bare minimum. The sausage was okay. The bacon was the best bet among the breakfast meats; but if you like your bacon crisp, you won't like it. The array of lox and fixin's for bagels looked pretty good, but we didn't try it. 

The pecan sticky rolls looked marvelous but were unfortunately disappointing. If you like oatmeal, there is a great selection of toppings. There was the usual huge array of buffet desserts.

There's a nice selection of flavored syrups for dressing up your coffee, but instead I added whipped cream. Delicious.

Now I'm not a buffet kind of person, but I wound up here this evening. Now why people would go here baffles me. The servers in the front are rude. No hello, hi, please, thank you, or you're welcomes from the lady Shirley. I felt like I was in a cattle herd waiting in the line and getting my way to the front. Lucky for me I had great company so I put up with it.
We got seated and went up to the buffet. This was the smallest buffet selection I have ever seen. (which I guess could be good because the food was awful.) I took a little bit of the buttered noodles which were so hard and crispy. nothing like a flimsy noodle should be. The beef in the asian dishes was extra chewy. I sampled some of the taco meat, mexican rice, and beans mixed all together on my plate and got a piece of plastic in my mouth. yes, you read right. PLASTIC in my food. I was instantly turned off from anything else. In order to please my party I ate a slice of pineapple, some cottage cheese, and the wimpy salad bar. As for dessert in the ice cream section they give you warm bowls. it melted my poor vanilla ice cream into soup.
This place just left me disgusted and sick to my stomach. That is hard to do but they sure did it.
Thanks paradise buffet. I will not be returning and you can keep your plastic with your rude employee's.

An inexpensive buffet to go to! It definitely is not the quality of Bellagio, Caesars, Wynn, etc., but it's a way to save money if you're willing to compromise quality. 

The one thing I do love is their breakfast buffet!!! I always get the omelette at the omelette bar. From that 1 omelette, you can already get your money's worth. Their fruit is always fresh and sweet! Their pancakes and belgian waffles were also amazing! Freshly made as well, so it's fluffy and soft :) 

Their dinner buffet; however, did not impress. I went on their Steak night and that was pretty good. Cooked to order however you would like. Got my money's worth on that. Their Chicken Marsala was also good; it wasn't dry...phewf! Those were the 2 things that stood out to me. Everything else was average. I didn't like their soft serve or froyo or whatever it was. It's more like ice milk? 

Also, if you want to do a la carte items, their Ox Tail Soup is really good and the portion is HUGE. Great flavors. When I got the saimen, it was soooo salty. I took out half the soup and added hot water. And even after adjusting the soup, I was soooo thirsty that night. 

I forgot who our server was, but she was so friendly! She has a very long braid with bangs I believe. Ramona? Bleh, I forgot, but I just wanted to mention her :)

This is a nice and affordable buffet located in the fremont casino. 

They have crab legs, crawfish, peeled shrimp, plus several hot dishes for your enjoyment. I don't remember having anything really great, but nothing was bad either. It was under $25, even less with our VIP card. Overall it was a good deal. 

Even though it's not an extravagant buffet on the strip, it's a great place to get full and enjoy eating with friends. The staff was friendly, and the wait was not long. Both pluses. 

They also have a full bar which is a big plus!

Not bad. What this buffet lacked in selection it more than made up with excellent service, a great price, and some tasty food. The fried chicken, prime rib, and chicken curry soup were fantastic. The desserts not so much. Meatballs were also good.

Far from impressed.  Not enough value for money.  I have been to sams town breakfast buffet and the paradise is the same menu but lacking the chef carved station, not to mention almost four dollars cheaper!!!

I was seated in the left nook area by kitchen doors.  While dining I could strangely smell cigarettes, disgusting! This area was server by waitress Maria.  She is attentive and nice, I did however hear her comment to a busboy about a "gorda" fat woman in spanish, this did offend me.

Not quite enough value for money, too heavy on "tourist tax"!

One star. Very misleading. Food was okay though. After shopping around, Norma at the cashier station stated bottomless mimosas was included with breakfast. When we wanted a 4th mimosa, we were told 'bottomless' means 3 max. And you are not allowed to mix them together. (We asked for a larger cup to mix the small glass of champagne and small glass of oj together and no one had an issue brining us them). The food and beverage manager Marco told us he felt 3 was plenty. If I wanted to have 3, I would have stated at arrival that I only wanted a few. He argued with my husband and refused service. Biggest waste of $40 in all of Las Vegas. You lost customers for life Fremont. Marco was extremely rude, interrupting my husband constantly about his right to refuse. You need to specify at arrival the meaning of 'bottomless'. Very displeased.
I went to the paradise buffet on fremont st. It was very good food the staff was very friendly and courteous they do a super job at the buffet
Our waiter was really attentive so that was nice. Everything else fell short. The food was not that good and the selection was small. Would not recommend and would not come back

I came here for the prime rib, it was decent. Overall food was good, seasoned just right. Buffet had a decent selection of food. Try the carrot cake with ice cream. Service was good, liked the decor of restaurant. I would definetly come back again and recomend this place
Please don't eat here unless you are elderly like ur meat well done not very good . Pricey

My friend Steve took me here 2 nights ago on St Patrick's day.for the seafood buffet dinner.It
was very good and had a good selection of various seafood items.I was a bit disappointed that they didn't have cocktail shrimp,only peel and eat but the rest of the items made up for that small detail.The price was not unreasonable for a seafood buffet,$22.95,as I've seen others that go for $25.00 or $30.00 Our server was pleasant.I would definitely recommend this buffet on seafood night ,as I was absolutely stuffed by the time I left.For other nights,you're on your own.

Thought it would be a bigger buffet. It has 8 different stations, each station has 3 bins of food to pick from except the dessert area which is huge. Food was ok but expected more, more flavor. Staff friendly. If u want to experience Vegas buffet go elsewhere. Old school joint right here!

We liked coming here for breakfasts but now its like they down graded. Soggy bacon sitting in oil & the Portuguese sausage in oil not that much selection now. I'll have to give it a 2 1/2 stars... Will have to stick to the main street buffet

Come here if your looking for some gastrointestinal issues while on vacation . Food was horrific, and service was subpar. We're walking out after tasting a little bit of everything. Bait and switch for sure! Not worth the money, take your ass to a strip club buffet instead...your in vegas for gods sale! #tastelikebootyhole

Really 2.5 stars
I went on a Tuesday evening, for the seafood buffet. $19.99/person

Pros: snow crabs legs are pre-cut to allow easy eating. Service was good. Plates were whisked away and drinks refilled rapidly. Selection of seafood items was surprisingly broad.
Oysters, peel and eat shrimp, cocktail shrimp, scampi, fried shrimp, fried calamari, cioppino, crawfish, smoked and prepared salmon, tilapia, mahi mahi, trout, mussels, maki, and sushi, maybe more I'm forgetting

Cons: most items were just good or ok. Nothing was great and a couple of things ( scampi and cocktail shrimp ) were yuck. Desserts uninspired complete with soggy canoli. Smoky atmosphere bothered my asthma, but this is Vegas, so that isn't a fair complaint.

If you are down here and you love crab as I do, its worth coming here and eating for the price. Don't expect to be blown away, but you can find something you enjoy eating and get your money's worth.

Nice buffet in old Vegas. After paying $60-70 a person for the buffet in Caesars. This was a delightful break with a $10 lunch. The food was pretty good. Better than fast food but not the fancy stuff like the strip might have. Good roast beef as well as a make your own burger bar. So if you are wanting a break from $50 a person meals, hop an uber or lyft and head to Fremont street and grab some grub from one of these older, cheaper, but still good quality buffets.

This was a last minute decision for my coworker and I to come here to the newly renovated buffet restaurant and enjoy some lunch.

Both of us has been here only once and didn't remember the experience from the previous experience.

The restaurant lounge has a very lush a floral-like decor to give you the impression of being somewhere exotic & tropical.

The food islands each have its own setting of food variances.

One is dedicated to freshly cut fruits, an assortment of melons and other well knowns.

There's a salad and cold cuts section with an assortment of premise salads like macaroni or potato salads.

In the middle, there's a build your own burger or hotdog station. It's a little confusing since you have a hot station for burger patty's, hotdogs, grilled onions, bacon strips, etc. 

The buns are located next to it and yet May and ketchup or cheese is nowhere to be found. Also, there's a soft serve ice cream section which is sort of in an odd place. The remainder of that island is a lie and dessert section hosting Apple, cherry, blueberry pies and the other end a variety of cakes.

Along the back wall is the hot food station.

Beef bourguignon, mashed taters, roast or fried chicken, roast turkey or beef carved slice by slice, fried rice or plain, potstickers, cornbread etc.

Also know that there is also an ala cartel menu that provides specific meals - half of it is for our Hawaiian O'Hana who may want local island fare.

Not too bad, the food was good, chicken was juicy, the customer service was amazing.

One fun story, after making my first plate of food, I walked back to my table and set my plate down, before I sat I was already starting a conversation when I looked at the other person and realized I was about to sit at the wrong table.

Enjoy!

:)

We came here because we were on Fremont Street and we were hungry and there's a sign outside the Fremont Casino advertising the "biggest and best" buffet on Fremont Street.  If this is the biggest and the best I would truly hate to see the others.  We were here on "steak night."  Price was $14.99/person.  I think you get a $1 discount if you have a players card for the casino.

I should probably preface this review by saying we ate at Bacchanal a couple days prior to eating here at the Paradise buffet.  I knew we would not get the same quality of food as at Bacchanal, but good lord... The salad bar was kind of gross.  Their "fresh meats and cheeses" section was packaged lunch meat and Kraft singles (probably generic, not even Kraft).  I am not kidding.  The hot food section was... limited.  I think there were maybe 10 food choices total with a meat carving section in the center.  One of the meats available was ham.  They had a maybe 2" thick end piece of a ham sitting there that was dry and crusty.  They never replaced it the whole time we were there (which, granted, was not long) and it never got smaller, which means no one else was foolish enough to ask for any either.

Being that it was steak night we expected to see steaks.  Well, there were some very thin cuts of steak being grilled.  They ask how you want yours cooked but there's really no point - the meat is so thin they're all well done.  As far as the other hot food went, the only 2 things I actually enjoyed were a baked potato and a fried chicken leg, neither of which was worth $14.99.  They had a porkchop dish that was downright disgusting.  I did find a basket of nacho chips and a pot of scalding hot cheese sauce.  These were edible and I did like the fact that the chips were thick.  I saw some sushi but didn't get anywhere near it.

Dessert... only the sugar free items were labeled so we took a couple of things back to our table to try (hoping to figure out what they were).  We tried two different pies that had absolutely no flavor, a piece of chocolate cake that was kinda rubbery, and a slice of cheesecake that my husband deemed "ok."  We left the desserts on the plates with small bites out of them.  As I was walking through the restaurant I noticed several other tables with plates of desserts on them that looked exactly like ours.  The service was just ok - we had to wait a while for someone to come take our drink order but our plates were always cleared promptly.

Bottom line, pay more for a better buffet on the strip.  I wouldn't come back here, even if it was free.

We happened to stop in here on steak night.  We were pleasantly surprised after reading some of the reviews.  The person cooking the steaks cooked them to our specification.  Food was as good as any other buffet we had eaten and cost less than many of them.  Good selection in all areas.  We would definitely eat here again.

Simple AYCE eatery located inside The Fremont Hotel.

Food is a basic buffet with an okay selection..great for the price but nothing too fancy.

Tables are plentiful and clean.  Wait help is courteous and quick to refill your included drinks.

Been here a few times and am always content when I leave.

I wanted to try one of the cheaper buffets off the strip, and Ishould've known...this place sucked! I went on a weekday for breakfast/ lunch and they were closing all the stations for breakfast and bringing out lunch items. I spent a little over $30 for 3 people. I did get a chance to get an omelet from the omelet station. The ingredients were strewn all over the place and not much to choose from. I watched the guy make the omelet but, he loaded it up inside on cold cheese AFTER cooking it so, by the time I sat down to eat it, it was lukewarm. The cheese was still cold and didn't even melt. I couldn't even cut into it. I ate a few pieces of bacon, a greasy, tasteless sausage patty, and some sauteed potatoes that were old and cold as well and 2 child size cups of warm apple juice. Once lunch entrees finally came out, it wasn't any better. I sampled a fried chicken wing, some instant mashed potatoes that obviously came out of a box, a piece of roast beef that was overcooked and was tough like shoe leather. I also had a piece of Italian sausage that was quite salty and greasy. All of it was inedible. I wouldn't recommend this place. I won't be coming back. The atmosphere is dark and cheap, and the people working there looks like they're sorry they work in such a dump. I ended up eating a plate of salad which was actually fresh but, was a little too wet from washing the lettuce. Toppings were very limited but, seemed somewhat fresh. However, I won't be returning. I'll stick to the resort buffets.

Worst buffet downtown besides Golden Nugget. Everything out of a box and as low quality as you can get. Oysters were stuck to the shell. Very old and smelled. Don't eat them. Better yet, stay away. Go to Main Street Station and the 777 Brew Pub.
Food is no. Better than a school cafeteria, bland,, typical cheap crap better to pay more.than come here

We need to remember a few things here:
1. This is not a strip buffet, don't go expecting a strip buffet
2.  It's not priced like a strip buffet don't expect a strip buffet
3. Don't complain about the lack of vegetarian options when you show up on STEAK NIGHT
4. Don't complain about the quality of steak when you are paying 15.49 a person. 

Fremont's buffet is great. We tend to go on steak night to get our fill for about 35 bucks with tip. Where are you going to find a decent steak you don't have to cook yourself for that price? You're not. They have good roast beef too. There's a little for everyone, but their selection is low in terms of variety, that's why I recommend going when it's a specials night that you'll enjoy. It's old decor reminds me of what Vegas used to be like and reminds me that not everything downtown is changing.

We loved the guy manning the grill on Wednesday. His sense of humor was great and he knows how to turn a not so great cut of meat into a good steak.

$27 for adult dinners. I expected $20, but after a day of $4 coffee and $8 burgers I just shrugged and went for it. Not worth that price. Tough fish, cold soggy crab legs...And as mentioned, some of the help has an attitude. The best thing there was the fried shrimp. I wouldn't go back, way over priced.

The selection of food was very minimal. The quality of food was very basic, cheap. Even the selection of drinks was minimal (pepsi, mountain dew and tea). Wont be back not worth it... would rather mcdonalds

Good buffet great price.  Sunday brunch was delicious.  We went back for breakfast on Monday still good.  Only thing was the guy on the omelets.  He gave my husband the wrong omelette and blamed him.  He needs to chill out.  Overall a good buffet for the price.

For only $13.99 with your B Connected card, this buffet is freaking cheap!  
Wednesday & Saturday = Steak Night $13.99
Sunday, Monday, & Thursday = Prime Rib Night $17.99
Tuesday & Friday = Seafood Fantasy $13.99
*These prices all take the B Connected card into account.  If you don't have one it will be $1 more.

I came on a Wednesday which was a Steak Night.  I love meat and the steaks are freshly grilled and seasoned the way you like it.  I really don't know what cut of meat it is but it is pretty good.  Don't expect gourmet steaks but it's fun!  The grill master was super kind and remembered that I like it medium rare when I went to get my second steak haha.  The meat itself is pretty thin so that they can cook faster.

The fried chicken was surprisingly good!  It was juicy on the inside and crunchy on the outside.  I also liked the potato bar... cheese, chives, butter, and sour cream.  Fatty style.

The desserts were not impressive.  They had a lot of choices to choose from... cheesecake, pineapple upside down cake, custard pie... but none of them were that great.  I just stuck with the vanilla soft serve and oreo chunks.

Service was great.  Our drinks were always refilled before they reached the bottom.  I haven't had the Seafood Fantasy or the Prime Rib, but I would probably choose another buffet for that type of food.  Steak night is fun though!  Try it out if you are in downtown and want a $14 buffet.

I stayed at the Plaza Hotel and wanted to enjoy a breakfast buffet. Went to Paradise twice. Very easy to get in. First time no waiting, second time short wait. Sat in a booth. It was dark and could use a little more light. Lots of choices. Kudos to the omelette chef: very friendly. I had the option to go to another buffet near the Fremont Street Experience but came back to Paradise. Would recommend to friends

Repulsive, filthy buffet.  The atmosphere was dark and the smell, terrible.  Me and my companion searched for something, anything that was edible, but found nothing.  The food was either too old or too bland.  There was a hobo sitting next to us with a bucket underneath his table.  He must of been hungry and desperate for food, because he was filling that bucket full of food to take out of the restaurant.  I'm shocked the staff was allowing him to do that.  Stay far away from this buffet, their food =pig slop.

I came here for the Sunday champagne brunch. Do yourself a favor and sign up for the players card. You might win a free meal here on your new member spin, but you'll get a buck off your buffet regardless. It's worth it, just do it. My cousin and I went for the crab legs and bacon. Everything else is about the usual buffet-quality. If you have kids, just make them biscuits with a bunch of meat in it, give them some dessert after. If you're having mimosas, count on having to constantly flag down a server for your refills. Just accept it. For the price you're paying, just shut up, sit down, and enjoy your fill.

I'm giving the Paradise Buffet an extra star, simply because it bludgeoned my friend's positivity until it was bruised plum purple. After a night of heavy imbibing and glass clinking abandon, we ended up here, in the early morning, with thoughts of fluffy flapjacks caroling in our mind. The buffet is relatively cheap - a few shillings and you're home safe - so we thought we would spin the bottle on this place. 

Immediately upon entering, the we noticed that most of the food was limp, lukewarm, devastatingly disappointing. My friend trudged and shuffled and bowed his head as if someone had just blindsided his soul. He compared the smells of this place to a a bleu cheese filled fish tank. While his statement was a hyperbole, it really didn't smell too appetizing. 

The lack of selections sent me into a frown-induced tailspin. Still, it's pretty funny to see your friends sink into a pit of despair at this place.

I was disappointed with this buffet.  No selection and very old food.  I personally have ate at the other Boyd Group buffets and always have had a great time. I almost asked for a manager to get our money back.  I would recommend Sam's Town, Orleans, and Main Street but not the Fremont Paradise Buffet.

I read the reviews before coming here and thought oh maybe everyone just has different opinions, no. I'm only 22 so my taste in food isn't super high class but I know nasty food when it's nasty. It's not dirty or anything, but your probably better off with a bar or a regular restaurant. Will not be returning


Oh and the crab legs were literally still frozen.

This is the cheapest buffet that I considered in Vegas, but you get what you pay for. Plus, parking is only free if you get a validation, so remember to save your receipt.

Granted, this place is in the Fremont Casino on Fremont, instead of south on the strip with the better and higher end casinos. I figure that is why this place is cheaper, but the food was not that good and the dining area could have used a good remodeling. Basically, this is in an older casino in the older part of Vegas that is last on the list of where tourists visit.

I also do not recommend getting there at the cut-off point between breakfast and lunch, because there is a several-minute delay in when the lunch items are brought out. When we went there to pay, we were told that we had 2 minutes left in the breakfast buffet and if we paid for that, then breakfast items would be cleared soon and we could not get any of the lunch items. And so we opted for the lunch buffet. Really, is the food police going to care whether I grab breakfast or lunch items?

I went ahead and grabbed a few breakfast items anyway, such as pancakes, bacon, and country-fried potatoes. The bacon had little to no taste, but the pancakes and potatoes were pretty decent. Then when some lunch items came out, I helped myself to those. The best thing there was the chicken breast.

Service is practically non-existent, and we ended up having to grab our own silverware and condiments. At least they took away dirty plates in a timely manner.

This buffet may be cheap and the best in the Fremont area, but that does not factor the strip into account. Next time I would pay the extra few bucks somewhere down south.

I've read all the reviews and watched the you tube videos on the Paradise Buffet. I have been in the past but it's been awhile. I decided to go to the Saturday Night Steak buffet and wow was I surprised. My  previous visits had been to their prime rib nights and I felt the food was a good value for the money. The steak night is not a piece a meat sitting in a warming tray. It's s steak cooked right in front of you to your liking. For the $15.00 tab the quality was very good and the rest of the buffet items were tasty as well.
Keep in mind we're talking one or two steaks cooked to order plus dozens of sides for the modest $15.00.
Other Boyd properties offer prime rib buffets as do most of the other
Hotels in town and you can pay all the way up to the $50 plus range.
 The Fremont Steak buffet is one of  a kind and will be on my list every time I'm in town on a Saturday evening.

The fried chicken is very salty and the food option are minimal. I would not recommend this buffet. It's Vegas you have too many more better options. 

On a good note, they have excellent service! Everyone was super nice.

This is located at the Fremont Hotel & Casino in Downtown Las Vegas. In the past I've eaten here pre Yelp days. People mostly eat here for the buffet which is not bad back in the day not sure about now. On Sunday morning we came here for the Cafe arrived at 8ish there was no line but all the tables were full they told us the crowd came at 7am when it opened, all the rest opened tables were only for the buffet which to me was kinda not right but I understand because they only had two waitresses working and later on two more showed up so they expanded the tables so we finally were seated. They do have a pretty selection of food to choose the breakfast was the deal though I should of gotten the French toast cause it looked yummy I got the two eggs rice and Portuguese sausage. Service was good and the food came out pretty quick. For price the cafe is ok vs doing the buffet unless you have coupons or a comp. I do prefer Market Street Cafe at the Cal over this.

Save your money and time !!!
With a ton a places to go and see this place is a waste of time and money , there is always a wait , we finally managed to go in , and asked if there was sushi and they said yes , just because they wrap up rice with seaweed doesn't make it sushi; they had nothing nothing at all ; for $25.00 each all I had was a baked potato and a paper thing slice of raw prime rib you're better off going to Siegel's just a block away at the Cortez there were a couple other option for food but nothing good or decent looking , way way to over rated

There are lots of great places to eat in Las Vegas.  The Paradise Cafe had a $20 seafood buffet that many patrons seemed to be enjoying.  We decided to dine off the menu.  We're were promptly taken to our table and as I sat down I couldn't help noticing the empty soup bowls on the next table.  After a nice conversation with a young couple and their friend they highly recommended the Oxtail Soup.  They mentioned that often come to Paradise Cafe just for this soup.  I wasn't disappointed!  It was a hearty & delicious soup with a wonderful Filipino/Hawaiian flavor that satisfies the soul.  It's worth a try if you're in the Fremont district.

I bookmarked this spot, because I read they had a decent buffet and for only $7.99, it was considered one of Vegas's best deals... That was then and this is now. I have no idea when that website was written, but we paid something along the lines of $12.99? I can't even remember. But it definitely wasn't $7.99. Anyway, it was still reasonable in our mind, so we walked in. 



BEWARE! They stop lunch service at 3 to set up for dinner at 4. I didn't know this, and we drove all the way from the Strip to try Paradise, so when I was turned down at 3:02pm, I gave them a small teensy tiny bitch fit. But only because I was standing right behind an older gentleman, who they let it at 3:01. If it was ok for him, it better be ok for us. And it was. 



They let us in and told us we had 15 mins to grab what we wanted and they were clearing out all the food. It was like Supermarket Sweep for us, we were given the green light, and packed two whole plates per person to make sure we got our fill. We ate and left full, and even with our late arrival, weren't the last ones out. 



A decent buffet for the price. They even had cocktail shrimp.

Came where because we were in Fremont and needed something to eat... food was ok at best, section was limited for the price, and service was nice but when I asked for water.. I still have gotten it as I write this review and so far it's been 20mins... and when I looked at another waiter he just looked at me with a dumbfounded look...

Crab legs on Fridays! Plus raw oysters so for that they get the four stars. Currently $21.99 so you can't beat that for all you can eat seafood. Not a big selection of food outside of the crab legs and the "fresh" sushi didn't look so good. The roast beef was OK but the brown gravy was not very good. If you don't like crab legs you probably should avoid this place.

We had breakfast here and it's all you can eat! They have everything breakfast style. Also had fruits, salad bar and ice cream. Price was $10 it is worth it if you are a breakfast lover. This restaurant is located in the Freemont hotel.

When my coworkers suggested this place for lunch I was not excited, but I trust them and they frequent this place so I stuck with their recommendations just to be safe.  Therefore the high rating only applies to the salad bar, seafood chowder, clam chowder, prime rib, fried shrimp and soft serve as that is all I really tried. The prime rib but it was a bit overcooked for my taste but it wasn't dry.  The seafood chowder was surprisingly good, flavorful and chocked full of seafood and I would return just for that.  The atmosphere reminded me of the Peppmermill with all the artificial flowers and it's definitely old Vegas as far as decor but at $11 for lunch it's a great deal if you're downtown.

Small buffet...  It had nacho/taco station, cold cut sandwich station, cold crab claws (not legs), prime rib, dinner sausage, small salad bar, 1 type of soup, fried chicken, rice (white and fried), dessert island, fish, and a few other things.  It was dingy and old.  The wait staff was nice.  $13.99 per person.  My dad like the prime rib; personally, nothing stood out.

Let me explain why gave it 5 stars: after spending $100s of dollars at the strip for pretentious food, I was so relieved to pay $20 for all we could eat buffet food! I mean, you get what you pay for and noone is trying to say otherwise. Paradise wasn't pretending to be anything else than a cheap buffet on Fremont. THATs why I loved it. 

The decor was awesome too! I mean come-on, how often do you go into a restaurant and feel like you're back in the 60s or 70s or watching Casino! It was great.

If you're pretentious and too "fancy" to eat in a place like this, than go to strip -its all good. 

Please don't get me wrong I have no problem spending money when the food is great but this time around we had so many misses and lots of expenditures that it was nice to not overpay for inexpensive food.

I've come here twice now and if you're eating in downtown you're not going to be expecting the BEST quality you'll find on the strip. Saturday nights are AYCE Steak night and at least you can get them cooked to order. They've also got crab claws but seems to still be defrosting and other variety of discount buffet foods from roast beef to stale baos.

We had been out the night before around Fremont Street, and the Paradise's greasy breakfast options hit the spot for the whole group (four of us).

The lunch options didn't look as enticing as the breakfasts, but really, it's so hard to go wrong with breakfast. 

If this was more than $15 (for breakfast) I probably wouldn't return, but at $8-9 it's perfect.
We paid 20$ all u can eat buffet and they had crab legs. They don't have much of a variety of other food but hey its 20$ less than what u pay at other buffets.
Decent buffet, great price (one of the cheapest for casino buffet in Vegas). Very good dessert selection.

I heard all the hype on Channel 5 Fox and took my visiting family to the Sunday buffet. How embarrassing.  The choices were scant; fish was not fresh; hot food was barely warm.  Selections not at all comparable to other buffets I have been too.  I will not be returning nor could I ever recommend

This review is mainly just for the oxtail soup. It was a huge bowl for a very good price (only $9.29), and it had a ton of meat. It wasn't the most tender oxtail I've had but it still tasted really good and the broth too. I  wouldn't come back for any of the other food, but I'd definitely come back for a big bowl of oxtail soup.

I don't really know how to define my experience here but I think Websters really nailed it....
The definition of Paradise is:
a place or condition of great happiness where everything is exactly as you would like it to be...

I've been here a handful of times with my partner & it is a magical place where we can unwind after a long trip. Most of the other patrons are old enough to be my grandparents & it really reminds me of what I want out of life if I can stop being reckless & manage to live more than another 4 years. I don't think I could ever ask for anything more than being at this buffet with the love of my life... except maybe for some better options for vegetarians- it's pretty heavily meat based buffet... 

...but besides that I'm in heaven when I'm at the Paradise!!
Tasty buffet for only $16.20 total! A little outdated decor, but quick staff and really delicious American menu items. I will be returning :)

This buffet needs some remodeling. The decor hasn't changed nor has the menu. 

While I do come here with my parents when we are on vacation, it's due to the fact that we use the coupon book for meals that we can use with our hotel package. If it wasn't for the coupon, this place would be a total rip off. 

So the only reason that I gave it a two star is due to the fact that the staff is friendly and if you have the coupon book then it's a decent deal for a meal.

I came here on seafood night (Tuesday). The food was decent not too much to rave about. The clam chowder was watery, the shrimp fried rice was flavorless. I did enjoy the hot crab legs (although they were kind of small). I just grabbed  bunch, took out all they meat, squeezed lemon on top with a bit of salt, and into the butter it went. Yummy! I also had the roast beef with mashed potatoes and gravy. That was pretty tasty!

The servers were very attentive, kept my drink full and my table clean.

Easter sunday dinner opened from 4pm.
8 years old kid also same price as $18.99-
not good selection at all.
after I had dinner, I got so thirsty. I guess they use too much salt on it.
I never go there.
not worth it. specially kids are same price as an adult.

3rd time at this place and not much to say. The food is ok. We were hungry so the food was adequate. Nothing significant about this buffet. The view of the big goldfish and pelicans was the most impressive thing to mention about Paradise Buffet.

This place has a poor selection of food considering the steep price around $14.95 per person for a typical buffet for brunch. We arrived after a couple of hours casino hopping because we were hungry and was let down. My party and I decided to only have a plate and wait for the crew to change the menu considering we arrived an hour before they would change the menu from brunch to dinner. So after waiting around 45 minutes and our stomachs not satisfied, we were kicked out. Totally beyond disbelief. Since when did buffets started kicking people out? Stay away from here for their breakfast and lunch sessions or you will be let down.

We were debating between grabbing a bagel in our hotel lobby or finding a place on Fremont Street for breakfast. We had a reservation for the Neon Museum tour and I didn't want to be late.

Let me start by saying that we ate here for breakfast on our first wedding anniversary, circa 1997. I discovered this cherry pastry that I thought about for years afterwards.

Yes, that was 18 years ago but there's a chance it might still be on the menu...right?

We saw a big sign from the freeway that said Free Parking, so we made our way to the outdoor lot. It turns out that you have to pay $3 but you can get validation and a refund at one of the many downtown casinos. The trick is to hang on to all the receipts & slips of paper the attendant hands to you. Keep it handy. We made our way inside the Fremont Casino and saw a sign that club members receive special pricing. Considering the fact that signing up for the card is free, why not? When the cashier handed my husband his new card, she instructed him to stick it in the machine and spin the wheel for a prize.

Guess what he won? Buy one, get one  1/2 off of a buffet. Eating breakfast here seemed to be our destiny. It's tough to pass up $11 for a buffet for 2. 

It was mid-week in October and we were seated right away. Our beverage waitress was very attentive and kept our coffee and waters full. That's where the stars stop for me. The mediocre sausage was cold. The pancakes and eggs tasted like they had been sitting awhile. There was a station where you could order an omelet but it had a pretty good line and I wanted to get on our way. If you find yourself here, that is definitely the way to go.

I avoided the canned fruit cocktail and selected a few pieces of fresh melon. The honeydew was fresh and tasty the cantaloupe was rock hard.

Remember the magical little cherry pastry I dreamed about for 18 years? Gone, replaced by lackluster little dry cinnamon swirls and puff pastries with more air than flavor. I was so sad.

We were told to go back to the cashier to get our parking validated. Remember when I told you to hang on to all the paperwork in the lot? This is where you will need it. We had to search for a good 10 minutes before we found the particular receipt they required to reimburse us the $3.

I went to the Fremont Hotel Casino intending on eating at Tony Roma's after seeing advertisements all over for a steak and lobster meal for $11.99. I showed up a little after 9pm when the deal starts, but the line was way too long. 
In the back of the casino, I saw Paradise Buffet, which was only $15. (with a players club card) and included New York steak on Saturday nights. 
After paying my $15. (which surprisingly included a drink), I was seated and went to make my plate. 
I was impressed by the cold cuts spread and the hot roast beef which was being carved. 
The New York was another story though. I ordered mine medium rare, but it ended up being way overcooked and very tough. The guy grilling them either misheard me, or he needs to find a new line of work. 
The price wasn't bad, but the steak was a huge disappointment. I had some tortilla chips too that were old and stale. The desserts did not look good at all, so I didn't even try any. I can't recommend this place at all. Spend a couple more dollars and go to a good buffet.
Been here a couple times with peeps who had coupons.  I enjoyed the Crab Legs and selection of food is decent.  Definitely a good spot if you got coupons.

The Paradise was always a "must do" while staying downtown. Loved the food, the garish tropical decore, and the limitless champagne served during weekend brunch.  And the price was outstanding! Please be sure to note the use of past tense in each of the preceeding statements.  Over the past few years, the quality and service has declined dramatically.  Last visit, the food was on par with the slop they served at the old Imperial Palace barffet and the wait staff couldn't be bothered.  Save yourself the trouble, and go to the Garden Court Buffet at Mainstreet Station.

Came here for lunch (Wednesday) ($9.99),,, price wasn't bad but the food quality is pretty bad. The Mac n cheese almost were stale and so were the  mashed potatoes. They barely even had anything. The staff and waiters are nice. If you're really starving then go ahead and come here I guess but they don't have much to offer(atleast the day we were here). The environment is nicely set up and comforting though with pretty decorations. Just the food is disappointing.
Great variety of food.  The price was reasonable, definitely plan on going back!

The Fremont Casino boosted that its' buffet is the "biggest and best" in the Fremont area.  Okay...that really doesn't say much since it's probably the only buffet in town.

I came here for the buffet since the price was hard to beat.  Buffets on The Strip were charging $11.99 up to nearly $35.00 so at $6.99, I couldn't resist.  Soon the phrase "you get what you paid for" kicked in.

First off, I came here right between the breakfast buffet cutoff.  The guy at the counter gave me two choices: either pay $6.99 for the limited breakfast buffet (whatever they haven't put away) or pay $7.99 for the lunch buffet (in which I was not allowed to eat breakfast items).  I didn't fully understand that kind of mindset but just to be on the safe side, I opted for the lunch buffet.

Once seated I noticed how dark, dingy, and outdated the dining area was.  The booth that I was sitting in had rips on the seat and the carpet was pretty stained.  After a few minutes, a server came and asked about drinks.  He brought the drinks to the table and I never saw him again.  In fact if I needed something like utensils, condiments, or extra napkins I got up numerous times to get them myself (*boo*).

It was 10 minutes until they bring out the lunch buffet items and yet I sat there not sure what to do.  Since I paid for lunch, I was told that I can't eat breakfast items.  And yet the time at the paid parking structure was ticking and I was quite hungry.  Since there were still a few breakfast items out, I went for it.  From what was left I got myself a sliver of cooked ham, one slice of whole wheat bread, half a spoonful of country potatoes, and (worst item ever) a very small amount of "eggs".  Nothing on my plate was appetizing but the "eggs" were just inedible.  It was not real but powdered "small curd cottage cheese like" eggs that tasted nowhere close to the real thing.  I had a forkful and discarded the rest.  The bacon was another story...not sure if it was a pig.  It tasted like cheap bacon with absolutely no smoky taste to it.

After what it seem to be forever, lunch items were brought out at 11 a.m.  Again the selection of food wasn't the greatest but I did like the grilled chicken, pork chops, and salad.  They had a "build your own" burger bar in which I grabbed myself a meat patty only.  It was fairly good but dry.  Fruit bar was also good but one side of the bar was completely empty and it stayed empty.  If I were to point out the "shiny star" of this buffet, it would be the dessert.  Many sweets to choose from and I did like the coconut white cake.

For what it's worth, I got.  It's not bad but it can use some improvement.  The size and variety of the selections can be bigger but I'm not really a fan of absent service and no acknowledgment.  

*Tip* if you parked in the Fremont parking structure, you can have your ticket validated at the Be Connected booth out in front but remember to bring your buffet receipt.

I met a friend from out of town and he picked this spot for our dinner get together.  It was a Monday and it was prime rib night.  Wait time was a minimum and we were seated fairly quickly and brought our drinks soon, too!

I went up and walked the line to see what they had.  It's not one of the better Boyd casino buffets.  They did however have some rare prime rib and that was my first stop.

I went back a second time and got some salad and other items that are different than other Boyd properties including pulled pork.

The dessert selection is OK.  

Overall, the place is OK but I wouldn't drive to Fremont Street to eat here.  There are so many better places near home that I wouldn't choose the Fremont.

This is not the most luxurious buffet in Las Vegas, but it definitely gives you the most bang for your buck! My husband and I were walking down Fremont Street, when we saw the sign with the prices for this buffet. They were definitely appetizing to our wallets, so we walked in to see what it was all about.

We didn't go in that day because we had already eaten, but we do keep in mind for the next time we came. We ended up coming again, and went into the buffet. We paid under $20 for both of us, and ate very delicious.

Their selection was good! Since it was the day after Thanksgiving they did have turkey and him, but they also had things like fish mashed potatoes fried rice lasagna salad shrimp soup etc. etc. 

We're going back today, because when we went last time we didn't have enough time to enjoy it. This time we're going to sit there and enjoy it! 

The customer service was also great, except at the end my husband and I got an ice cream and they didn't want to let my husband leave the place with his ice cream. The funny thing is, I just walked out of the place with my ice cream. Oh well!

I came here with low expectations from yelp users. So much negativity on this buffet...

But not from me! I fancy myself a frequent buffet guest of Fremont / the strip and I have seen the good, bad, and ugly. 

This buffet was well stocked with traditional american breakfast staples and some Asian influenced choices as well. 

French toast was perfect.  Cinnamon rolls were delicious! Bacon was crispy. And service was stellar! They get the drinks for you and plates are cleared almost immediately. Remember to tip the staff, preferably in cash!

Final thoughts... well worth the $10 after tax! I will be back soon to try their lunch and dinner offerings which sound great! Get the rewards card and save yourself a dollar.

Mom was in town from Maui for one of her famous gambling 'binges', so since she was staying at the lovely Fremont Hotel & Casino in Downtown LV we ended up going to the Paradise Buffet.  Friday night, Seafood 'Fantasy' night!

But alas, it was all just lackluster.  I'm sorry but I even forgot to take pics of my encounter with this lacking buffet.  I know for many tourists (especially Hawaii folks) just a buffet in general with all-you-can-eat crab legs is an endless wonder.  But when you're an LV local like myself you kinda expect more from your buffet!  Paradise Buffet was just borderline OK for me, not much I could find outstanding.

The crab legs are decent and plentiful at the buffet, but most of them are cold!  I like my crab legs warm, but there is not really any station setup for them to serve warm crab legs.  I don't think you can hand one of the chefs your plate and ask them to steam them for you either.  Wouldn't that be funny!  All I can say is please don't try this.  Do not interfere with an already disgruntled, busy chef.  That's asking for trouble!

Most of the other offerings at Paradise Buffet were lacking as well.  The baked fish was alright, but after sitting under the heat lamp too long some pieces were tough.  Just FYI, if you go on a Friday night, it is mostly SEAFOOD being offered!  So if you're a meat-only type of person this is not your night.  Although they do serve a nice prime rib with au jus, which probably was the best thing I ate that night.  Medium-rare, extra au jus, and creamy horseradish on the side?  Made for some good eating.  But this is Las Vegas, every casino here has some kind of prime rib...it's practically a staple!  

The other seafood choices didn't impress me much.  The fried clams were either soggy or overcooked.  The pasta was eh, just pasta.  And the Mexican offerings that night were NO BUENO.  Just flavorless.  Don't get me started on the sushi that is served RIGHT NEXT TO the soft serve ice cream machine!  Talk about fusion!  Unfortunately the sushi was just plain terrible, dry rice & suspect raw fish.  Even the basic Cali Roll was falling apart.

Besides the prime rib, the only other saving grace at this buffet for me was the sandwich station located at the salad bar.  Yes, the sandwich station.  Make your own sandwich with thinly sliced ham, turkey, or roast beef!  Then pick a cheese or 2!  I think only cheddar & mozzarella was offered that night.  A roast beef & turkey sandwich with cheddar and a ton of mayo helped save my sanity.  It wasn't gourmet, but it was familiar. 

Hardest part about this buffet for me to swallow is that it's like $22 per person, that's with the B Connected players card!  Without the card it's an extra BUCK.  For me the value just wasn't there.  You can go to a local Chinese buffet with all-you-can-eat crab legs and still pay less than you would here.  And you can get Mongolian stir fry included!  And the very same soft serve ice cream machine.

Sorry to say Paradise Buffet, not impressed.  You're not bad, but for the price I would have rather have gone to a Station Casino buffet for less.  It might not have the crab legs but I could have done without them.  But don't get me wrong, the tourists love you!

#crabby

This place was a joke.

First off, we were only fourth in line and it took almost fifteen minutes to get in.  They had one woman working at the register, and she kept ignoring the giant line to serve the people coming up to the "preferred" line.  She didn't smile and was generally unpleasant.

Then came the food.  In a town where there are buffets with literally hundreds of options, this particular place only had maybe 12 different food selections aside from the salad bar.  The roast beef was cold, the crab legs were so thin there were basically no meat in them and the sushi was lower quality than what you would expect to find at a local 7-11.

Just when we thought it couldn't get worse, the service was something just as bad. After waiting for a refill for quite some time, my cousins wife asked a server for a refill and she responded with "what do you want?". 

Save your money and try anywhere else.

Nothing over-the-top. Average food for a buffet, so with that said, it's overpriced. We came in for dinner. Service was average from the cashier to the person who handled the table. The place appeared clean.

I'm not a fan of red meat, especially steak. ICK. But when it's chicken-fried and covered in country gravy, it's amazing. I've never had chicken-fried steak before, let alone eat an entire steak on my own. This was deeelish!! Comes with a side of mashed potatoes and corn, a perfect combination. I came here twice within 5 days. My cousins swear by the philly cheese steak sandwich. I also had the chicken on sourdough sandwich which was yuuuuumy too. When my cousin was ordering her meal, the waitress even suggested on how to order the same thing, but cheaper. I'm definately coming back here next time I'm in Vegas!

One of the best buffet's Las Vegas has to offer. Great ambiance! Great service and best of all, Great food. Nice selection but taste is far above all the other buffets in town. The prime rib was outstanding, rare and juicy! The deserts were very good with a nice selection of cakes and pies. Yogurt available with toppings. I will return because the chef who oversees the place is doing a great job in food prep. Try the mussels in the red sauce.
